title: Genesis Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 31.

questions.question: What did Laban's sons say about Jacob in Genesis 31:1?
options: Jacob hath taken away all that was our father's
Jacob hath built a new house
Jacob hath fled from our father
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob hath taken away all that was our father's
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:1 states that Laban's sons said, 'Jacob hath taken away all that was our father's.'

questions.question: How did Jacob perceive Laban's countenance according to Genesis 31:2?
options: It was not toward him as before
questions.correctAnswer: It was not toward him as before
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:2 says Jacob beheld Laban's countenance and saw it was not toward him as before.

questions.question: What command did the LORD give Jacob in Genesis 31:3?
options: Return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred
Build an altar on the mountain
questions.correctAnswer: Return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:3 records the LORD commanding Jacob to return to his father's land and kindred.

questions.question: Who did Jacob call to the field to speak with them according to Genesis 31:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Rachel and Leah
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:4 says Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field unto his flock.

questions.question: True or False: Jacob served Laban with all his power as stated in Genesis 31:6.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:6 confirms that Jacob served Laban with all his power.

questions.question: What did Laban do to Jacob's wages according to Genesis 31:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Changed them ten times
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:7 says Laban deceived Jacob and changed his wages ten times.

questions.question: What type of cattle did Jacob's wages involve as mentioned in Genesis 31:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Speckled and ringstraked
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:8 describes Jacob's wages as speckled and ringstraked cattle.

questions.question: Who appeared to Jacob in a dream as described in Genesis 31:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of God
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:11 states the angel of God spoke to Jacob in a dream.

questions.question: True or False: Rachel stole her father's images as told in Genesis 31:19.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:19 says Rachel had stolen the images that were her father's.

questions.question: What was Jacob's reason for fleeing secretly from Laban according to Genesis 31:31?
options: He feared Laban would take his daughters by force
He wanted to visit his father
questions.correctAnswer: He feared Laban would take his daughters by force
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:31 records Jacob's fear that Laban would take his daughters by force, prompting secret flight.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Then Jacob took a ______, and set it up for a pillar.' (Genesis 31:45)
questions.correctAnswer: stone
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:45 states that Jacob took a stone and set it up for a pillar.

questions.question: What name did Laban give to the heap made as a witness between him and Jacob? (Genesis 31:47)
questions.correctAnswer: Jegarsahadutha
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:47 records that Laban called the heap Jegarsahadutha.

questions.question: What did Laban say should happen if Jacob's daughters were afflicted or if he took other wives? (Genesis 31:50)
options: No man is with us; God is witness between me and thee
They should be punished by God
questions.correctAnswer: No man is with us; God is witness between me and thee
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:50 says if Jacob afflicts the daughters or takes other wives, no man is with them and God is witness.

questions.question: True or False: Laban kissed his sons and daughters and blessed them before departing according to Genesis 31:55.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:55 states that Laban kissed his sons and daughters and blessed them before he departed.

questions.question: How long did Jacob serve Laban before fleeing, as stated in Genesis 31:41?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:41 mentions Jacob served Laban for twenty years in total.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling discouraged by unfair treatment at work. Based on Genesis 31, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance and God's care?
options: God sees our affliction and sustains us even when others deceive us
We should retaliate immediately against those who wrong us
Success is guaranteed if we work hard without complaint
God only blesses those who never face difficulty
questions.correctAnswer: God sees our affliction and sustains us even when others deceive us
questions.explanation: Jacob experienced deception and unfair wages multiple times (Genesis 31:7, 31:41) yet God did not allow Laban to harm him and saw his affliction (Genesis 31:42). This teaches us to trust God's sustaining care through trials.

questions.question: How does Genesis 31 teach about honesty and integrity in work?
options: Jacob did not eat the young of the flock or take what was torn, showing faithfulness
It is acceptable to deceive your employer for gain
Working long hours is the only requirement for success
Ignoring God's guidance leads to prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob did not eat the young of the flock or take what was torn, showing faithfulness
questions.explanation: Jacob states he did not eat the rams of the flock nor took what was torn (Genesis 31:38-39), reflecting integrity and faithfulness in his labor despite hardships, teaching the value of honesty at work.

questions.question: What does Jacob's obedience to God's command to return to his homeland teach about faith and trust?
options: Obedience to God's direction brings protection and blessing
We should rely solely on our plans without seeking God
Fear should stop us from following God's call
God's guidance is optional and can be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's direction brings protection and blessing
questions.explanation: God told Jacob to return to his kindred and promised to be with him (Genesis 31:3, 31:13). Jacob obeyed despite risks, teaching the importance of trusting and obeying God's instructions.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive a family member who has wronged them repeatedly. What biblical truth about forgiveness and reconciliation is seen in Genesis 31?
options: Jacob and Laban made a covenant and parted with blessings, showing reconciliation
Holding grudges is necessary to protect oneself
Revenge is God’s way of justice
Ignoring conflict is the best solution
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob and Laban made a covenant and parted with blessings, showing reconciliation
questions.explanation: Despite past deceit, Jacob and Laban established a covenant (Genesis 31:44-53) and parted with blessings (Genesis 31:54-55), illustrating the biblical principle of reconciliation and peace.

questions.question: How does Rachel and Leah’s response to Jacob's plan to leave teach about contentment and trust in God's provision?
options: They recognized that what God had taken from their father belonged to them and trusted God's plan
They demanded a portion of their father's house before leaving
They refused to leave their father's home
They tried to stop Jacob from obeying God
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized that what God had taken from their father belonged to them and trusted God's plan
questions.explanation: Rachel and Leah acknowledged that God had taken the riches from their father and given them to Jacob, so they encouraged obedience to God’s word (Genesis 31:14-16), reflecting trust and contentment.

questions.question: What does Jacob’s refusal to tell Laban about his departure immediately reveal about prudent discretion in difficult situations?
options: Sometimes discretion and caution are necessary to protect family and plans
Honesty should always be immediate regardless of consequences
Confrontation should be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes discretion and caution are necessary to protect family and plans
questions.explanation: Jacob fled without informing Laban (Genesis 31:20) because he feared Laban might forcibly take his daughters (Genesis 31:31), showing thoughtful prudence when facing potential harm.

questions.question: True or False: Jacob served Laban with all his power and loyalty despite being deceived multiple times.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jacob explicitly states he served Laban with all his power and remained faithful despite Laban's repeated deception (Genesis 31:6-7).

questions.question: True or False: Laban was allowed by God to harm Jacob during his pursuit.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God warned Laban in a dream not to speak to Jacob either good or bad, preventing him from harming Jacob (Genesis 31:24, 31:29).

questions.question: When Jacob saw the speckled and ringstraked cattle in a dream, what did this vision signify about God's involvement in his life?
options: God was aware of Laban’s deceit and was orchestrating events to bless Jacob
The cattle’s markings were random and had no meaning
Jacob should have ignored the dream
God was punishing Jacob for leaving
questions.correctAnswer: God was aware of Laban’s deceit and was orchestrating events to bless Jacob
questions.explanation: The angel told Jacob in the dream that God had seen all that Laban did and that the speckled and ringstraked cattle were a sign that God was in control (Genesis 31:10-12).

questions.question: How does Jacob’s faithfulness despite hardships teach us about perseverance and trust in God’s timing?
options: Jacob endured drought, frost, and sleepless nights but remained diligent and trusted God
He gave up quickly when faced with difficulty
He tried to gain success by dishonest means
God abandoned Jacob because of his troubles
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob endured drought, frost, and sleepless nights but remained diligent and trusted God
questions.explanation: Jacob explains the hardships he endured (Genesis 31:40) yet remained faithful in his service, exemplifying perseverance and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in their family life. What does Genesis 31 teach about God's role in family provision and protection?
options: God protects and provides for the family when we trust and obey Him
Family hardships mean God has abandoned us
Provision comes only from human effort without God’s involvement
Family blessings are based on personal power only
questions.correctAnswer: God protects and provides for the family when we trust and obey Him
questions.explanation: God promised Jacob His presence and protection when he returned to his family (Genesis 31:3, 31:13), demonstrating God's care over family provision and safety.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be learned from Rachel’s excuse when Laban searched for his idols?
options: Rachel humbly explained her condition, showing a modest and truthful response
She accused others to cover her act
questions.correctAnswer: Rachel humbly explained her condition, showing a modest and truthful response
questions.explanation: Rachel told Laban she could not rise because of the 'custom of women' (Genesis 31:35), showing humility and tact in a difficult situation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jacob set up a ______ as a witness between him and Laban to mark their covenant.
questions.correctAnswer: pillar
questions.explanation: Jacob set up a stone as a pillar, which served as a witness between them (Genesis 31:45, 31:51).

questions.question: How does the covenant between Jacob and Laban teach about resolving conflicts biblically?
options: Making a clear agreement with witnesses and invoking God as judge promotes peace
questions.correctAnswer: Making a clear agreement with witnesses and invoking God as judge promotes peace
questions.explanation: Jacob and Laban made a covenant with a heap and pillar as witnesses and called on God as judge, demonstrating biblical conflict resolution (Genesis 31:44-53).

questions.question: What does Jacob’s statement about God being the God of Bethel reveal about the importance of remembering God’s past faithfulness?
options: Remembering God’s faithfulness strengthens our courage to obey Him
Forgetfulness of God’s help is wise
Our past experiences with God are irrelevant to current decisions
We should rely only on present feelings
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering God’s faithfulness strengthens our courage to obey Him
questions.explanation: Jacob recalls God as the God of Bethel who appeared to him before, encouraging him to rise and obey God’s command (Genesis 31:13), showing the power of remembering God’s faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Genesis 31 teach about the importance of family unity and support in difficult decisions?
options: Rachel and Leah supported Jacob’s decision to obey God despite their uncertain future
Family members should always put self-interest first
Ignoring family input leads to peace
Decisions should be made without consulting others
questions.correctAnswer: Rachel and Leah supported Jacob’s decision to obey God despite their uncertain future
questions.explanation: Rachel and Leah acknowledged God’s hand and encouraged Jacob to do what God said (Genesis 31:14-16), showing the value of family support in obedience and faith.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 31.

questions.question: What reason does Jacob give for secretly fleeing from Laban without informing him?
options: He feared Laban would take his daughters by force
He wanted to avoid paying more wages
He was commanded by an angel
He sought to steal Laban's cattle
questions.correctAnswer: He feared Laban would take his daughters by force
questions.explanation: In Genesis 31:31, Jacob explains he fled secretly because he feared Laban would take his daughters by force.

questions.question: Which divine figure appeared to Jacob in a dream to instruct him to return to his homeland?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of God
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:11 records that the angel of God spoke to Jacob in a dream, instructing him to return to his kindred.

questions.question: How does the narrative describe the changing of Jacob's wages by Laban?
options: Laban changed them ten times to deceive Jacob
Jacob voluntarily gave up his wages
They agreed on fixed wages with no changes
questions.correctAnswer: Laban changed them ten times to deceive Jacob
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:7 and 31:41 mention that Laban changed Jacob's wages ten times to deceive him.

questions.question: What strategy did Jacob use to increase his flock according to the text?
options: He selectively bred speckled, ringstraked, and grisled rams
He bought more livestock from neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: He selectively bred speckled, ringstraked, and grisled rams
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:8-10 describe how Jacob used selectively breeding speckled, ringstraked, and grisled rams to increase his flock.

questions.question: What is the significance of the names 'Galeed' and 'Mizpah' given to the heap of stones?
options: 'Galeed' means 'heap of witness' and 'Mizpah' signifies 'the LORD watch between us'
'Galeed' is a personal name and 'Mizpah' is a place name
questions.correctAnswer: 'Galeed' means 'heap of witness' and 'Mizpah' signifies 'the LORD watch between us'
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:47-49 explains that 'Galeed' refers to a heap of witness and 'Mizpah' indicates God's watchfulness as a witness between Jacob and Laban.

questions.question: What cultural practice does Rachel invoke to avoid revealing her stolen idols to Laban?
options: The custom of women during menstruation
questions.correctAnswer: The custom of women during menstruation
questions.explanation: In Genesis 31:35, Rachel says she cannot rise before her father because of the custom of women, implying menstruation, which culturally exempted her from standing.

questions.question: What is the primary theme illustrated by the repeated changing of Jacob's wages by Laban?
options: The superiority of wealth over family
questions.correctAnswer: Divine providence protecting the righteous
questions.explanation: Despite Laban's deceit (Genesis 31:7, 31:41), God protected Jacob's interests, illustrating divine providence over human scheming.

questions.question: What did Laban accuse Jacob of doing when he fled secretly?
options: Stealing his daughters and fleeing like captives
questions.correctAnswer: Stealing his daughters and fleeing like captives
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:26 shows Laban accusing Jacob of stealing his daughters and carrying them away as captives taken with the sword.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 31, God commanded Laban to harm Jacob during the pursuit.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:24-29 reveals that God warned Laban in a dream not to speak good or bad to Jacob, forbidding harm.

questions.question: Which location is associated with Jacob's vow and the pillar he anointed, as recalled by the angel in the dream?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:13 states the angel identified himself as the God of Bethel, where Jacob had anointed a pillar and made a vow.

questions.question: How long did Jacob serve Laban in total before fleeing, according to his own words?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:38-41 recount Jacob's service of twenty years in total for Laban's daughters and cattle.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'heap' and 'pillar' made by Jacob and Laban?
options: They are a physical covenant and boundary between the two parties
They mark the burial place of Laban's ancestors
They symbolize Jacob's claim to the land
They are monuments to the victory over enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They are a physical covenant and boundary between the two parties
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:44-52 details the heap and pillar as witnesses and boundaries in a covenant between Jacob and Laban.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is illustrated by God's protection of Jacob's flock and destiny despite human deceit?
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty over human affairs
questions.explanation: Throughout Genesis 31, God's protection of Jacob despite Laban's deception illustrates divine sovereignty, a recurring OT theme (Genesis 31:7-9).

questions.question: What was Rachel's action regarding her father's household gods, and how did it affect the narrative?
options: She stole them, causing suspicion and tension
She gave them as gifts to Jacob
She hid them in the field
questions.correctAnswer: She stole them, causing suspicion and tension
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:19 and 31:34-35 reveal Rachel stole her father's images, which caused Laban to search and created conflict.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'The LORD watch between me and thee, when we are absent one from another' in the covenant?
options: It reflects a mutual trust under divine surveillance
It is a curse invoking destruction upon oath-breakers
It indicates a temporary truce during war
It mandates separation of families forever
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a mutual trust under divine surveillance
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:49 states Mizpah means the LORD watches between them, emphasizing divine oversight fostering trust in the covenant.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did God give Jacob for returning to the land of his fathers in Genesis 31?
options: God promised to be with him
God commanded him to build an altar
God told him to seek a wife there
questions.correctAnswer: God promised to be with him
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:3 states that the LORD told Jacob to return to his kindred and promised to be with him. This reflects God's providential guidance and faithfulness (cf. Exodus 3:12, Joshua 1:5, Isaiah 41:10, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: How did Jacob describe his service to Laban in Genesis 31?
questions.correctAnswer: With all my power
questions.explanation: Jacob states in Genesis 31:6 that he served Laban with all his power, indicating diligent and faithful labor. This aligns with biblical teaching on faithful stewardship (Colossians 3:23, Proverbs 22:29, 1 Corinthians 4:2, Ephesians 6:7).

questions.question: What method did Jacob use to increase his flocks according to Genesis 31?
options: Breeding speckled, ringstraked, and grisled cattle
questions.correctAnswer: Breeding speckled, ringstraked, and grisled cattle
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:7-12 describes how Jacob selectively bred the cattle to produce speckled and ringstraked offspring, which God blessed. This demonstrates God's sovereign providence and blessing on faithful labor (Psalm 1:3, Deuteronomy 28:4, Proverbs 3:9-10, James 1:17).

questions.question: What did Rachel and Leah say about their status in their father's house?
options: They felt like strangers and questioned their inheritance
They were beloved daughters with full inheritance rights
They had no concerns about inheritance
They planned to stay with their father
questions.correctAnswer: They felt like strangers and questioned their inheritance
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:14-15 shows Rachel and Leah expressing that they were treated as strangers and sold by their father, reflecting themes of alienation and injustice within families (cf. Hebrews 11:37, Psalm 27:10, Isaiah 54:7, Galatians 4:30).

questions.question: What did Jacob do secretly when he fled from Laban?
options: He stole away unawares without telling Laban
He left after a formal farewell
questions.correctAnswer: He stole away unawares without telling Laban
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:20 states Jacob fled secretly without informing Laban, reflecting the tension and fear in his departure. This illustrates the complex human dynamics in God's unfolding plan (cf. Exodus 1:15-21, Acts 9:23-25, Matthew 10:23, Psalm 32:7).

questions.question: How did God intervene when Laban pursued Jacob?
options: God warned Laban in a dream to speak neither good nor bad to Jacob
God sent an angel to fight for Jacob
God caused a storm to stop Laban
questions.correctAnswer: God warned Laban in a dream to speak neither good nor bad to Jacob
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:24 reveals God’s intervention through a dream, showing divine protection and restraint in human conflict (cf. Judges 6:11-23, Daniel 7:1, Matthew 2:13, Acts 10:3-6).

questions.question: What accusation did Laban make against Jacob after overtaking him?
options: That Jacob had stolen his daughters and fled secretly
That Jacob had stolen his cattle
That Jacob had spoken ill of him
That Jacob had broken a covenant
questions.correctAnswer: That Jacob had stolen his daughters and fled secretly
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:26-27 records Laban accusing Jacob of secretly stealing away with his daughters, illustrating human conflict and the complexities of family and covenant relationships (cf. Genesis 34:14-30, Exodus 20:12, Matthew 10:35-36, Romans 13:7).

questions.question: Why did Jacob say he hid the fact that Rachel had stolen Laban's household gods?
options: He feared Laban would violently take his daughters
He wanted to keep the gods for himself
He did not notice the theft
He planned to return the gods
questions.correctAnswer: He feared Laban would violently take his daughters
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:31 explains Jacob’s fear of Laban forcibly taking back his daughters, showing human fear and distrust despite God’s providence (cf. Genesis 34:25-26, Proverbs 3:5-6, Psalm 56:3, 2 Timothy 1:7).

questions.question: How did Rachel hide the household gods from Laban?
options: She put them in the camel’s furniture and sat on them
She buried them in the field
She hid them in a cave
questions.correctAnswer: She put them in the camel’s furniture and sat on them
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:34 shows Rachel cleverly hiding the idols by sitting on them, demonstrating human cunning contrasted with divine sovereignty (cf. Judges 17:5-6, 1 Kings 18:21, Isaiah 44:9-20, John 4:24).

questions.question: What was Jacob’s response to Laban’s accusation and search?
options: He questioned what he had done to deserve such pursuit
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned what he had done to deserve such pursuit
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:36 records Jacob’s anger and questioning of Laban’s harsh pursuit, reflecting human appeal for justice and God’s defense of His servants (cf. Psalm 35:1-8, Job 13:18, Isaiah 41:10, Romans 8:31).

questions.question: How long did Jacob say he had served Laban, and how were his wages changed?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years; changed ten times
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:38-41 shows Jacob’s testimony of faithful service for twenty years with wages changed ten times, illustrating perseverance and God’s protection amid human injustice (cf. Psalm 27:5, Ecclesiastes 3:1, 2 Timothy 4:7, Hebrews 12:1).

questions.question: What reason did Jacob give for not being sent away empty-handed by Laban?
options: The God of his father was with him
questions.correctAnswer: The God of his father was with him
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:42 attributes Jacob’s preservation to the God of Abraham and Isaac, highlighting divine faithfulness and covenantal promise (cf. Genesis 12:2-3, Joshua 21:45, Hebrews 6:13-18, Romans 4:20-21).

questions.question: What did Laban propose to establish between him and Jacob after their dispute?
options: A covenant with a heap of stones as witness
A battle to settle the matter
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant with a heap of stones as witness
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:44-48 describes the making of a covenant with a heap of stones as a witness, symbolizing a solemn agreement under God’s oversight (cf. Joshua 24:26-27, 2 Samuel 3:12-16, Ezekiel 20:37, Hebrews 8:6).

questions.question: What name did Laban give to the heap of stones, and what does it mean?
questions.correctAnswer: Jegarsahadutha, meaning witness heap
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:47 records Laban calling the heap Jegarsahadutha, which means heap of witness, signifying the covenant between them. This fits biblical themes of covenant witnesses (cf. Genesis 28:18, Deuteronomy 27:2-8, Psalm 89:34, Matthew 26:28).

questions.question: What did the name Mizpah, given to the heap, signify in the covenant between Jacob and Laban?
options: The LORD will watch between us when we are apart
The site of a future temple
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will watch between us when we are apart
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:49 states Mizpah means the LORD watch between me and thee when we are absent one from another, emphasizing God's role as covenant witness and protector (cf. Genesis 28:16-17, Psalm 121:4, Jeremiah 32:40, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: How did Laban conclude his departure from Jacob and his family?
options: He kissed his sons and daughters and blessed them
He cursed Jacob and departed angrily
He took some of Jacob’s cattle
questions.correctAnswer: He kissed his sons and daughters and blessed them
questions.explanation: Genesis 31:55 recounts Laban’s affectionate farewell with kisses and blessing, showing reconciliation and peace despite previous tensions (cf. Ruth 1:9, 2 Samuel 14:26, Numbers 6:24-26, Luke 24:50).
